1020 COMMERCE DR,

Re: License #: CI790363049

Dear Ms. Taylor:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
2

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 7/30/24, a staff punched a youth in the eye resulting in
redness in the youth's eye.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/31/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A
reported he was not punched in the eye by any staff at the facility.
Youth A reported he fought Youth C in the cafeteria on 7/30/2024
and staff broke up the fight. As Youth A was moving away from
Youth C, Youth D came from behind and punched him in the eye.
Youth A reported Youth B was present and witnessed the incident.
Youth A did not recall which staff were present.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/31/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B
reported he has never witnessed any staff punch or hit any youth
at the facility. Youth B reported Youth D punched Youth A in the
eye during a fight.
Youth D was interviewed via teams on 8/22/2024. Youth D
reported he fought Youth A in the cafeteria and punched Youth A
in the eye. Youth D reported staff intervened and broke up the
fight.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 8/7/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported she was
working when Youth A fought with Youth C and Youth D on
7/29/2024. Staff 2 did not know if Youth A was hit in the eye. Staff
2 reported Youth A attempted to fight with several youth on
7/29/2024.
Staff 6 was interviewed via telephone on 8/15/2024. Staff 6
reported Youth A fought Youth C and Youth D in the cafeteria.
Staff 6 reported she was present and intervened to stop the fight.
Youth A fought Youth C and they were separated. Youth D came
up behind Youth A and punched him in the left eye. Staff 6
reported no staff punched Youth A.
3

Lead Supervisor was interviewed via telephone on 8/7/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Lead Supervisor reported
Youth A fought “several peers” Monday (7/29/2024) and Tuesday
(7/30/2024). Lead Supervisor reported Youth A fought Youth C
and Youth D. Several staff, including Lead Supervisor and Staff 2
intervened and stopped the fights. Lead Supervisor was unsure if
Youth A got punched in the face. Lead Supervisor reported Youth
A was not hit by any staff. Lead Supervisor never noticed Youth A
to have a swollen eye.
Nurse was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/31/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Nurse reported she
examined Youth A on 7/30/2024 as Youth A was punched in his
left eye by a peer, unsure which peer. Nurse reported she
completed a neuro exam and eye exam and no concerns were
noted.
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/31/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Administrator
reported Youth A was punched in the eye by a peer however was
unsure which peer. Administrator reported Youth A attempted to
fight several youth at the facility. Administrator was present during
the fights and intervened to stop the fights. Administrator reported
she did not see any youth make contact with Youth A however
Youth A reported he was hit by a peer in the eye.
Video Viewed:
Video footage of 7/30/2024 in the cafeteria was reviewed on
8/8/2024. Staff 10, Staff 11, Staff 12, and Lead Supervisor are in
the cafeteria with Youth A, Youth C, and Youth D. Youth A ran
toward Youth C and Youth D. Lead Supervisor stood in between
Youth A and Youth D. Youth A went toward Youth C and began
hitting Youth C. Lead Supervisor attempted to get between Youth
A and Youth C. Youth C hit Youth A back. Staff 10, Staff 11, and
Staff 12 assisted Lead Supervisor in getting between Youth A and
Youth C. Youth A backed up and placed his hand on his face and
appeared to be rubbing his eye. It is difficult to see if Youth C
punched Youth A in the left eye as the altercation happened
quickly. Youth D was not viewed to hit Youth A in the video clip.
Administrator reported she was unable to locate the video clip
where Youth A was hit by Youth D.
Documents Reviewed:
• Wolverine Human Services Policy for Prohibited
Interventions: Use of physical discipline inflicted in any
manner is prohibited.
4

• Wolverine Human Services Nurse Note for Youth A dated
7/30/2024 completed by Nurse: Youth A reported he was
punched by another client and pointed to his left eye.
There was no immediate bruising, swelling, or redness
present. Youth A denied any pain. Neuro assessment
within normal limits and baseline for Youth A.
• Wolverine Human Services Incident Report for Youth A
dated 7/29/2024: Youth A was assaulting a peer. Staff
were separating the youth when another youth ran up and
began punching Youth A. Youth A was punched by a peer.
• Email dated 8/20/2024 from Administrator: Administrator
was unable to locate the video clip where Youth D punched
Youth A in the eye.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interview with Youth A
he reported he was not punched in the eye by a staff. Youth A,
Youth B, Youth C and staff interviews confirmed Youth A was not
punched in the eye by a staff.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth sprained their finger and has not been provided medical
treatment.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/31/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A
reported he jammed his finger playing basketball over the
weekend and reinjured his finger during a fight on Monday. Youth
A reported he saw Nurse a few times for his finger however he
was unable to recall when he first saw Nurse. Youth A reported
he went to urgent care on 7/30/2024 and received a finger splint to
wear for two weeks. Youth A reported he did not fill out any
medical request paperwork to see Nurse. Youth A reported he
saw Nurse on 7/30/2024 and she recommended he go to urgent
care. Youth A reported he was taken to urgent care.
5

Nurse was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/31/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Nurse reported she
examined Youth A on 7/29/2024 for a jammed finger after
reviewing an incident report from the weekend that indicated
Youth A jammed his finger. Youth A’s finger had minimum
swelling. Nurse had Youth A do a range of motion exam and
Youth A reported that he was having difficulty bending his finger.
Due to Youth A’s report of difficulty bending his finger, Nurse
recommended Lead Supervisor and Staff 2 take Youth A to urgent
care on 7/29/2024. Nurse assessed Youth A for a separate
reason on 7/30/2024 and Youth A reported his finger was still
bothering him. Nurse followed up and found Youth A was not
taken to urgent care on 7/29/2024 however did not know why.
Nurse again recommended Youth A be taken to urgent care on
7/30/2024. Nurse reported she did not know if Youth A was taken
to urgent care on 7/30/2024 as it takes a few days to receive
medical reports from the hospital. Nurse reported Youth A should
have been taken to urgent care on Monday as she gave the
directive to Lead Supervisor and Staff 2 as the medical
professional at the facility and it was her clinical assessment and
recommendation. Nurse informed Administrator on 7/30/2024
Lead Supervisor and Staff 2 did not follow her medical
recommendations. Nurse reported she saw Youth A later in the
day on 7/29/2024 and witnessed he was moving office furniture
and appeared to be having no difficulty with his finger.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 8/7/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported she and
Lead Supervisor were present when Youth A saw Nurse however
Staff 2 could not recall the date. Nurse recommended Youth A
have Ibuprofen and go to urgent care to have his finger assessed.
Staff 2 reported Youth A was taken to urgent care and his finger
was assessed however she did not recall the day Youth A was
taken to urgent care. Staff 2 reported she was not aware of any
delays in Youth A going to urgent care.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 8/14/2024. Staff 3
reported she took Youth A to urgent care with Staff 4. Staff 3
reported she does not work in Youth A’s unit. Staff 3 assists with
transporting youth at the facility when needed. Staff 3 had no
further information on who recommended or when it was
recommended Youth A go to urgent care.
Staff 4 was attempted to be contacted via telephone on
8/14/2024, 8/20/2024, and 8/22/2024. Staff 4’s voicemail box is
full and a message is unable to be left. Staff 4 is on leave from
6

the facility until 9/19/2024 and the facility does not have any other
telephone numbers for Staff 4.
Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone on 8/14/2024. Staff 5 did
not recall if he worked when Youth A jammed his finger playing
basketball however Youth A told Staff 5 about it after the fact.
Youth A showed Staff 5 his finger and reported it occurred playing
basketball. Staff 5 did not recall anything about Youth A seeing
the Nurse on 7/29/2024 or 7/30/2024. Staff 5 had no knowledge
of Youth A going to urgent care for his finger.
Staff 6 was interviewed via telephone on 8/15/2024. Staff 6
reported she routinely works on Youth A’s unit. Youth A jammed
his finger playing basketball. Staff 6 had no knowledge if Youth A
was referred by Nurse to go to urgent care or if Youth A was taken
to urgent care.
Staff 7 was interviewed via telephone on 8/20/2024. Staff 7
reported she works first shift and would have worked on
7/27/2024. Staff 7 did not recall Youth A hurting his finger. Staff 7
reported she did not recall or have any information about Youth A
seeing Nurse on 7/29/2024 or 7/30/2024. Staff 7 did not know if
Youth A was recommended to go to urgent care or if Youth A was
taken to urgent care. Staff 7 did not recall Youth A complaining
about finger pain.
Staff 8 was interviewed via telephone on 8/20/2024. Staff 8
reported she was contacted, unable to recall the date, to take
Youth A to urgent care however Youth A reported he had already
been taken that morning. Staff 8 reported she was aware Youth A
had been examined by Nurse however did not recall the date.
Staff 8 did not know if Nurse had recommended Youth A be taken
to urgent care. Staff 8 reported Youth A was taken to urgent care
as he had a finger splint.
Staff 9 was interviewed via telephone on 8/14/2024. Staff 9
reported he was not aware of Youth A hurting his finger playing
basketball and had no knowledge of Youth A seeing Nurse or
being taken to urgent care.
Lead Supervisor was interviewed via telephone on 8/7/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Lead Supervisor reported
she became aware Youth A had a jammed finger on Monday.
Lead Supervisor reported Youth A saw Nurse. Nurse
recommended Youth A go to urgent care. Lead Supervisor did
not recall what day Nurse recommended Youth A go to the urgent
7

care. Lead Supervisor believed Youth A went to urgent care on
the day Nurse recommended he go. Lead Supervisor believed
Youth A went on Tuesday (7/30/2024). Lead Supervisor reported
she recalled Youth A fighting several peers on Monday. Lead
Supervisor reported it would have been the supervisor on the unit
Youth A was on to make the decision for him to go to urgent care
that night. Lead Supervisor reported she was not the supervisor
on shift on 7/29/2024 and believed Staff 2 was. Lead Supervisor
reported she did not know why Youth A would not have been
taken to urgent care on 7/29/2024 per Nurse recommendation.
Therapist was interviewed via telephone on 8/14/2024.
Therapist had a session with Youth A on 7/30/2024 and Youth A
complained that his finger hurt. Therapist viewed Youth A’s finger
to be swollen. Therapist contacted Nurse who examined Youth
A’s finger and sent him to be checked out at urgent care.
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/31/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Administrator
reported Youth A was seen by Nurse for his finger. Nurse
recommended on 7/29/2024 Youth A go to urgent care for his
finger however Youth A was not taken on 7/29/2024 due to Youth
A having unsafe behaviors. Youth A was attempting to fight
several youth at the facility and was escalated until 11:30pm.
Nurse examined Youth A’s finger again 7/30/2024 and Nurse
recommended again Youth A go to urgent care. Youth A was
taken to urgent care on 7/30/2024. Administrator reported she
had no idea what happened to Youth A’s finger. Administrator
reported the only reason Youth A was not taken to urgent care on
7/29/2024 as directed by Nurse was due to his unsafe behaviors.
Documents Reviewed:
• Wolverine Human Services Health related resources,
procedures, and oversight Policy: WHS residential
programs are residential level of care, therefore are
responsible to coordinate multiple services to clients in care
and programs. The range of services offered is available
24/7 for 365 days per year. The following is the overview of
the programs regarding services and coordination of health
resources, procedures and services. All WHS clients
receive ongoing, coordinated services based on assessed
needs and goals.
• Wolverine Human Services Nurse Note for Youth A dated
7/29/2024 completed by Nurse: Youth A’s left index finger
was assessed due to a basketball injury over the weekend
at 11:15am. Left index finger observed with minimal
8

swelling. Youth A was able to bend finger partially. Youth
A reported pain was a 5 on a scale of 1-10, now pain is a 3.
Youth A used ice and ibuprofen with little relief. Nurse
advised Lead Supervisor to have Youth A taken to urgent
care for evaluation.
• Wolverine Human Services Nurse Note for Youth A dated
7/30/2024 completed by Nurse: Youth A reported his left
index finger still hurt. Nurse notified Lead Supervisor via
electronic communication to send Youth A to urgent care
for evaluation and treatment as indicated.
• Wolverine Human Services Incident Report for Youth A
dated 7/29/2024: Youth A was assaulting a peer. Youth A
reported his pointer finger and right thumb were sore.
Youth A was provided ice but declined pain medication.
• Covenant HealthCare Office Visit notes for Youth A dated
7/30/2024: Youth A presented with left hand index finger
injury that occurred playing basketball. Youth A reported
his finger was bent back yesterday causing more pain.
Diagnosis: Sprain of metacarpophalangeal joint of left
finger. Xray showed no obvious fracture. Youth A was
provided a finger splint.
• Logbook dated 7/27/2024 documented Youth A injured his
finger playing basketball at 2:30pm. Youth A was not seen
by medical, follow up is needed, and an incident report was
completed. Logbook documents GLBH (Great Lakes Bay
Health) was called.
• Email from Administrative Coordinator dated 8/14/2024:
Incident report was unable to be reviewed as the facility
reported they were not able to locate it even though the
logbook indicated one was completed. GLBH was
contacted to request documentation of the call however the
nurse on call did not note the call.
• MiSACWIS social work contact dated 8/13/2024 between
MDHHS Worker and Medical Provider: Medical Provider
examined Youth A’s finger on 7/30/2024. Youth A’s finger
was jammed playing basketball on 7/27/2024. Medical
Provider stated Youth A had a sprained finger with no
fractures or dislocations. Medical Provider reported he did
not have any concerns with Youth A not being seen until
7/30/2024 as the injury was a sprain and noted many
people don’t even come in for this type of injury as it will
heal on its own.
9

• Email from Administrative Coordinator dated 8/13/2024:
7/29/2024 first shift staff were Staff 4, Staff 5, and Staff 7.
Second shift staff were Staff 6, Staff 8, and Staff 9. Shift
Supervisor on 7/29/2024 was Staff 2. Youth A was taken to
urgent care on 7/30/2024 by Staff 3 and Staff 4.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance. Nurse examined Youth A
on 7/29/2024 and made the medical determination for Youth A to
be taken to urgent care. Nurse provided Staff 2 and Lead
Supervisor with the direction for Youth A to be taken to urgent
care, however, Youth A was not taken to urgent care on
7/29/2024. Nurse examined Youth A again on 7/30/2024 and
learned he was never taken to urgent care on 7/29/2024. Per
interviews with staff, it is unclear why Youth A was not taken to
urgent care on 7/29/2024.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered for the facility to implement a
policy/procedure to address when facility medical staff make
medical recommendations the expectation of the
recommendations be followed in specified timeframe and who is
notified, responsible and ensure the medical treatment is received.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Youth nutrition
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4149
Section (1) A licensee shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious edible meals
Description daily unless medically contraindicated and documented.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Three units were served spoiled milk on 7/30/24. Youth are
provided expired food and little time to eat.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/31/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A
reported he received spoiled milk at lunch on 7/29/2024. Youth A
reported he knew the milk was spoiled as it smelled and was
“gooey”. Youth A told Staff 1. Staff 1 smelled the milk and told
Youth A to throw it away. Youth A reported he did not drink the
milk. Kitchen Staff 2 was working in the kitchen on 7/29/2024.
Youth A reported he “thought” he told Kitchen Staff 2 the milk was
spoiled. Youth A reported he received an expired Rice Krispy
treat on 7/30/2024. Youth A knew the Rice Krispy was expired as
it was turning different colors and part of it was black. Youth A did
10

not eat the Rice Krispy treat. Youth A did not recall if he told any
staff or youth about the Rice Krispy treat being expired. Youth A
reported he has not received any other spoiled milk or expired
food at the facility. Youth A reported he receives enough food to
eat at the facility and he has never been hungry.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/31/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B
reported he has received spoiled milk four times this week at the
facility, twice at breakfast and twice at dinner. Youth B reported
the milk inside the carton was spoiled as it was “clumpy” and
“poured out like glue”. Youth B told staff about the milk on
7/30/2024 however did not recall who he told. Youth A showed
Youth B today that his milk was spoiled. Youth B reported on
7/28/2024 he received French toast cracker bites with his meal
and the crackers were stale. Youth B did not eat the crackers, he
threw them away. Youth B reported he receives enough to eat at
the facility however he would like to have more time to eat as
youth are only given a short period of time to eat (this is being
addressed in special investigation 2024SIC0001596). Youth B
reported one youth took some of his breakfast once. Youth B
refused to provide the youth’s name who took his food or provide
any further information. Youth B reported if youth take his food
again in the future, he has staff he can go to about this.
Youth C was interviewed via teams on 8/22/2024. Youth C
reported he receives three meals and one snack a day at the
facility. Youth C reported he has never had spoiled or expired
milk or food at the facility.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 8/13/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 was informed by
Youth A and Youth B a couple weeks ago at breakfast that their
milk was spoiled. Staff 1 reported Youth A and Youth B informed
her the milk was spoiled as the expiration date on the carton was
the date they were drinking it. Staff 1 reported she checked the
milk, and she thought it did smell as if it was spoiled. Staff 1
reported she informed Kitchen Staff 2 and Kitchen Staff 2 the date
on the milk expired the day it was being drank and Kitchen Staff 2
said to drink it. Staff 1 reported there have been five to six times
when she has noticed milk being served two to three days after
the expiration date on the milk carton. Staff 1 reported there has
been issues with youth slamming milk cartons in the milk cooler
causing milk cartons to bust open and spill onto other milk
cartons. Staff 1 reported when this happens, Kitchen Staff 1 and
Kitchen Staff 2 clean out the spilled milk, however there are times
11

that she thinks some of the milk on the bottom is missed. Staff 1
reported the milk crates on the top of the milk cooler are the milks
that are expiring first. Staff 1 reported she feels as though the
Kitchen Staff 1 and Kitchen Staff 2 try to be mean and hurtful if
kids are disrespectful or mess up the kitchen area and tell the kids
to just drink the milk. Staff 1 reported youth are able to have juice
as well with breakfast and lunch, and water with all meals. Staff 1
reported she does not feel the youth receive enough fluids at the
facility. Staff 1 would like to see the facility provide youth with
more fluids including cold water as Staff 1 reported the water the
youth drink is from the water fountain, and it is not cold. Staff 1
reported milk is now kept in the kitchen and Kitchen Staff 1 and
Kitchen Staff 2 put the milk out for mealtimes. Staff 1 reported no
knowledge of expired food being served at the facility.
Staff 2 and Lead Supervisor were interviewed via telephone
on 8/7/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Neither
reported having any knowledge of spoiled milk or expired milk
being served at the facility.
Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone on 8/14/2024. Staff 5
reported he was not present however Youth A and Youth B told
him they had spoiled milk at the facility. Staff 5 reported he also
had spoiled milk at the facility in June 2024. Staff 5 reported there
was a whole crate of milk that was dated to expire the day it was
put out to be drank. Staff 5 reported he considered the milk
spoiled as he did not believe the facility should serve milk on the
date that it shows it expires. Staff 5 did not have any other
concerns about expired or spoiled food at the facility.
Kitchen Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/31/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Kitchen Staff
1 reported she had no knowledge of any of the youth receiving
spoiled or expired food. The facility receives milk deliveries every
Wednesday from Prairie Farm. Kitchen Staff 1 reported there has
been a few occasions where milk cartoons are smashed in the
cooler which has caused milk to get on the outside of other milk
containers causing the outside milk on the container to smell
spoiled. Kitchen Staff 1 reported the last milk delivery did have a
few chocolate milk cartoons that were smashed however she was
unsure if it was from the youth or Prairie Farms. Kitchen Staff 1
reported she has never seen the milk to be “gooey” or spoiled in
the individual milk containers.
Kitchen Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 8/21/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Kitchen Staff 2 reported the
12

facility does not serve spoiled milk. Kitchen Staff 2 reported per
his ServSafe training, milk can be served two weeks past the
expiration date however this does not occur. Milk at the facility is
not served after the date it shows it expires. Kitchen Staff 2 gave
the example of the milk expiration date being 8/21/2024, he would
serve that milk on 8/21/2024 however at the end of the evening
any milk remaining with the expiration date would be placed in the
locked cooler to be thrown away in the morning. The locked
cooler is not accessible by any youth or staff other than kitchen
staff. Kitchen Staff 2 reported he places the milk in the locked
cooler as it is dark out when he leaves so, he waits until morning
to throw it away. Kitchen Staff 2 denied ever serving milk past the
expiration date. Kitchen Staff 2 reported some youth and staff, he
was unable to provide specific names, will say the milk is expired
if it is served on the date which it expires, and he has told them
that is not accurate and to drink the milk. Kitchen Staff 2 reported
there has been ongoing issues with milk arriving from the delivery
and anywhere from six to twelve cartons being broken causing
milk to spill on other cartons and at time create a spoiled smell.
Kitchen Staff 2 has cleaned the milk cartons when he has noticed
spilled milk however there are times the crates are at the bottom,
and he is unaware. Kitchen Staff 2 reported when he arrives at
work at the beginning of the week, he checks the milk for
expiration to know what he has in the milk cooler until the next
delivery and monitors the expiration dates. Kitchen Staff 2
reported there was a time when the facility received a delivery of
milk and the milk all expired before the next weeks delivery.
Kitchen Staff 2 reported he threw away all the expired milk and
went to the store and bought gallons of milk to get through until
the next milk delivery. Kitchen Staff 2 reported any time a youth or
staff has come to him and stated the milk they had was spoiled,
he has told them to throw it away and provided them another milk.
Kitchen Staff 2 reported he has never saw clumpy spoiled milk at
the facility. Kitchen Staff 2 denied ever serving expired milk as a
way to be mean and hurtful if kids are disrespectful or mess up the
kitchen area and tell the kids to just drink the milk. Kitchen Staff 2
reported he had no knowledge about expired snacks ever being
served at the facility.
Director of Operations was interviewed via telephone on
8/8/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Director of
Operations manages kitchen operations. Director of Operations
reported food for the facility is received from Gordon Food
Services and milk is ordered through Prairie Farms. Milk is
delivered to the facility every Wednesday. Director of Operations
reported there have been a few issues with the milk Prairie Farms
13

has delivered this summer regarding expiration dates not being far
out. Director of Operations was notified by Kitchen Staff 2, unsure
the date, who was going through the milk and some of the
expiration dates were only three days out. Director of Operations
informed Kitchen Staff 2 to throw the milk out and to go buy
gallons of milk from the store to get through until the next milk
delivery. Director of Operations reported the facility cannot and
does not service expired milk. When milk is delivered to the
facility on Wednesdays, the kitchen staff go through the milk
cooler and move the new milk to the back and the milk that needs
to be used first to the front. Director of Operations reported there
was recently an issue with the youth reaching to the back of the
milk cooler and taking the newest milk first and smashing milk
cartons in the milk cooler as the milk cooler was put out in the
cafeteria for the youth to obtain their milk. Since this issue was
recognized, the milk cooler is now kept in the kitchen and the
kitchen staff provide milk to the youth. Director of Operations
reported kitchen staff check the milk cooler daily or every other
day to ensure there is no milk expired or expiring soon which is
how Kitchen Staff 2 found the milk that was expiring resulting in it
being thrown away. Director of Operations reported at times there
are some milks with holes that do leak on other cartons which
make the milk carton smell spoiled. Kitchen staff take out any milk
that they see that have holes however if it is in a milk crate on the
bottom of the cooler that is not seen right away, it may be missed.
The milk cooler holds twelve milk crates in total. Director of
Operations reported she has heard some youth say the milk is
spoiled however the milk is not per the carton date. Director of
Operations has never seen any milk inside a carton to be sour or
thick. Director of Operations reported youth have options of milk,
juice, and/or water at breakfast and lunch, and milk and/or water
at dinner. Director of Operations reported if a youth claimed their
milk was spoiled, kitchen staff would provide them another milk.
Director of Operations has no knowledge of any french toast
crackers being served that were expired. The facility does have
Rice Krispy treats and serves a variety of flavors including plain,
confetti, chocolate chip, and chocolate. Director of Operations
has no knowledge of any expired Rice Krispy treats being served
that were turning different colors due to being expired.
Nurse was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/31/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Nurse reported she has
not had any medical complaints or assessed any youth at the
facility regarding food illness. Nurse reported she has not had any
youth make statements to her regarding spoiled milk or food being
expired.
14

Therapist was interviewed via telephone on 8/14/2024.
Therapist was informed by Youth A he had spoiled milk. Therapist
did not see or smell the milk. Therapist has not had any other
youth make complaints to her regarding spoiled milk. Therapist
reported she drinks the milk at the facility and has never had a
spoiled milk.
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/31/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Administrator
reported the youth at the facility eat three meals a day and receive
one snack. Breakfast is at 6:20am, lunch is at 11:20am, dinner is
at 4pm, and evening snack is at 7:15pm. Administrator reported
youth receive ten minutes for breakfast, and thirteen minutes for
lunch and dinner (this is being addressed in special investigation
2024SIC0001596). Administrator is unaware of any spoiled milk or
expired food being served at the facility.
Tour:
A tour of the kitchen was completed on 7/31/2024. The milk was
observed to be kept in a separate refrigeration system on wheels.
The milk was cold, and the dates of the milk were observed, and
no concerns noted. The milk expirations date varied from
8/6/2024, 8/11/2024, and 8/13/2024. There was no spilled milk on
any of the milk cartoons or in the milk refrigerator.
Documents Reviewed:
• Wolverine Human Services Client Nutrition/ Meals and
Snacks Policy: Wolverine Human Services will provide a
minimum of three (3) nutritious meals each day and a daily
snack based upon a written menu meeting the nutritional
allowances recommended by the Michigan Department of
Public Health.
• Wolverine Human Services Summer week 3 menu was
viewed, and no concerns were noted.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as there was conflicting
information regarding spoiled milk being served at the facility.
Based on interviews, some staff report milk is busted in the milk
refrigerator causing milk to spill onto other containers causing
some milk cartons to smell spoiled. Some interviews suggested
milk was served spoiled as it was served on the date the milk
carton showed was the expiration date. Regardless, no youth was
forced to drink expired milk.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
15

• Kitchen staff check milk expiration dates daily to ensure
milk is not being served after the expiration date.
• Kitchen staff continue to check for any spilled/broken milk
containers and clean the milk refrigerator.
• If a youth expresses concerns with their milk being spoiled,
a new milk be provided to the youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

Description communication that ensures that a child is able to communicate
with family and friends in a manner appropriate to the child’s

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4136
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a written policy regarding
Description recreational activities, equipment maintenance, appropriate

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth is sometimes not offered recreational time.
17

Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/31/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A

minutes and all youth are able to attend. Youth A reported
recreational time consists of basketball. Youth A reported he

Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/31/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B
reported sometimes he does not get recreation time and the last
time he did not get recreation time was Monday. Youth B did not
know if other youth got recreation time on Monday. Youth B likes
to spend time in the gym. Youth B did not have any additional
information or concerns to report about recreation time.

any youth not receiving recreation time.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 8/7/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported all youth at
the facility receive recreation time daily for forty-five minutes to an
hour. Recreational activities include basketball, flag football, catch

Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone on 8/14/2024. Staff 5

Therapist was interviewed via telephone on 8/14/2024.

facility. Therapist was only aware of one incident where there

18

7/31/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Administrator
reported having no knowledge of any youth not receiving
recreation time.
Documents Reviewed:
• Email from Administrative Coordinator dated 8/6/2024
indicated Wolverine Human Services does not have an
official policy on recreation time. Youth are offered sixty
minutes of recreational time daily which includes inside and
outside activities.
• Clarence Fischer House Daily Schedule indicates
structured activity time daily from 5pm-6:15pm as well as
additional times varying depending on the day.

Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as the facility does not
have a recreation policy and procedure. Youth B indicated he has
